full_text: In this short demonstration, we take a look at the Security Dictionary. The Security Dictionary describes security permissions and roles in BillingCenter, and the relationships among them. The Security Dictionary is generated initially when BillingCenter is installed. The dictionary can be regenerated at any time to reflect the current BillingCenter configuration. In the top left, we see the four types of information contained in the dictionary. Below the summary link, you see the list of application permission keys. Application permission keys are sets of permissions that BillingCenter groups together for performance reasons. I'll start by clicking the summary link. The right-hand pane shows permissions grouped by entity. It also shows the permission settings at the time the dictionary was generated. I can select a permission to view its description, permission name, and PCF references to the permission. For example, I'll click Account Close. I see the name of the permission is ACCT Close, and there are two PCFs where the permission is referenced. Next, let's click the Pages filter. The Pages section lists each PCF screen page in the user interface and the permissions needed to view or edit that page, if any. For example, I'll click Account Detail Charges. Here we see that a user needs two permissions to visit this page. Permission to view the Account tab and, permission to view Account Charges. I'll scroll up to Accounts. I click the Accounts link. The Account tab view permission is required to view and edit accounts. Without this permission, a user would never see the Accounts tab. Let's scroll back to the top of the page. Next, we'll look at System Permissions. I'll click the System Permissions filter. The System Permissions section of the Security Dictionary lists each permission, alphabetically by internal code. We just looked at the permissions for visiting Account Detail Charges. Now let's take a look at the permission that is involved. This is where we can see the roles that contain this permission, the application permission keys that contain it, and the pages and user interface elements that reference it. Let's see what permissions the Billing Manager role contains. All of the permissions for a Billing Manager are listed here. The final filter is Roles. I'll click the link. This time, let's look at the Billing Clerical role. Like the Billing Underscore Manager role, Billing Underscore Clerical has several permissions. You can see the Security Dictionary contains a lot of useful information about roles and permissions. Keep in mind that the Security Dictionary is a series of static HTML pages. If changes are made to the permissions in a given role, the Security Dictionary must be regenerated to reflect those changes. Users, groups, and security zones are not included in the Security Dictionary. They are part of the data model, which is described in another dictionary, the Data Dictionary. The actual users, groups, and security zones are simply data that is stored in the Billing Center database. This concludes our demonstration on the Security Dictionary.

segments.text: In this short demonstration, we take a look at the Security Dictionary. The Security Dictionary describes security permissions and roles in BillingCenter, and the relationships among them. The Security Dictionary is generated initially when BillingCenter is installed. The dictionary can be regenerated at any time to reflect the current BillingCenter configuration. In the top left, we see the four types of information contained in the dictionary. Below the summary link, you see the list of application permission keys.
Application permission keys are sets of permissions that BillingCenter groups together for performance reasons. I'll start by clicking the summary link.

The right-hand pane shows permissions grouped by entity. It also shows the permission settings at the time the dictionary was generated. I can select a permission to view its description, permission name, and PCF references to the permission. For example, I'll click Account Close.
I see the name of the permission is ACCT Close, and there are two PCFs where the permission is referenced. Next, let's click the Pages filter.
The Pages section lists each PCF screen page in the user interface and the permissions needed to view or edit that page, if any. For example, I'll click Account Detail Charges.
Here we see that a user needs two permissions to visit this page. Permission to view the Account tab and, permission to view Account Charges.
I'll scroll up to Accounts. I click the Accounts link. The Account tab view permission is required to view and edit accounts.
Without this permission, a user would never see the Accounts tab. Let's scroll back to the top of the page.
Next, we'll look at System Permissions. I'll click the System Permissions filter.
The System Permissions section of the Security Dictionary lists each permission, alphabetically by internal code.
We just looked at the permissions for visiting Account Detail Charges.
Now let's take a look at the permission that is involved.
This is where we can see the roles that contain this permission, the application permission keys that contain it, and the pages and user interface elements that reference it.
Let's see what permissions the Billing Manager role contains.
All of the permissions for a Billing Manager are listed here. The final filter is Roles. I'll click the link.
This time, let's look at the Billing Clerical role.
Like the Billing Underscore Manager role, Billing Underscore Clerical has several permissions.
You can see the Security Dictionary contains a lot of useful information about roles and permissions.
Keep in mind that the Security Dictionary is a series of static HTML pages.
If changes are made to the permissions in a given role, the Security Dictionary must be regenerated to reflect those changes.
Users, groups, and security zones are not included in the Security Dictionary.
They are part of the data model, which is described in another dictionary, the Data Dictionary.
The actual users, groups, and security zones are simply data that is stored in the Billing Center database.
This concludes our demonstration on the Security Dictionary.
